title: What are the relationships of applied social science and social science? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question I think being asked here is how does pure science translate into practical application. In physical sciences, chemistry, physics, etc perform experimental research that expands basic knowledge in form of theory which engineering and medicine use for practical application. In Social Sciences, Psychology and Economics dominate the quantitative experimental and pure research of human and market behavior. The ideas, models, theories, measurement procedures, and jargon developed at the University and published in professional journals are adopted by practitioners in Education, Criminal Justice, Social Work, Business Marketing, Political Science, etc. The applications are sometimes quantitative (statistical survey for political polls), but more often the general principles are used for specific problem solving with qualitative analysis. So, for example, modern cognitive psychology theories for aggression and depression help improve applications in law enforcement and social services beyond the old fashioned moral traditions or Freudian principles from the past. The more practitioners understand how people actually think and behave, the better the prediction and chances for improvement. There is also an increasing success with complex data driven statistical analysis in modern applied social sciences within business marketing, advertising, and social services based on modern cognitive psychology model applications. Needless to say, modern economic theory has gone a long way toward allowing the government, through Federal Reserve and other institutions, to flatten the business cycle and reduce recurring recessions compared to boom and bust cycles of the past century. One major difference between hard sciences, which are 100% math dependent, and applied social sciences, which still require human judgement to solve human problems, is that practitioner age and experience is more important in applied social sciences. There are few young geniuses is the social arena because besides ample depth of social theory, practitioners must be deep in individual case study and history in order to be effective. Also, some gain is still made in a purely qualitative way. Historians and sociologists must read large volumes of literature from the archives of libraries before developing the generalized models of understanding about which they write.

“Social Science” is the entire area of scientific endeavor related to discovering facts (i.e. very strong theories) about humans and other social animals; in this latter connection it is part of a continuum from biology and ethology. As you can see, it is a very broad field that includes ethology, anthropology, sociology, economics, psychology, linguistics, and several other more specialized fields. Any “applied science” researches how the particular science can be used in the real world for beneficial results. Thus, “applied social science” explores how the notions of theorists and the findings of experimentalists in any of the social science fields can be used in the day-to-day world. This is the realm of ethics and the sweet/scary potential of such knowledge. And it is not a “pie in the sky” concern. Marketing, advertising, and the legal system are principal users of this kind of knowledge. Those Russian hackers who influenced the 2016 election? They were using social science principles to sway voters en masse. So, too, the daily advertisers that you hear on radio, and see on TV or the social media. Similar principles are used to make products, services, and values appealing to any who may be influenced, whether it’s by “big pharma,” a government, or your local church.

I believe I have previously answered a simular question. Basically I believe that Social Science and applied Social Science are basically the same thing. Social Science is about people how they interact with others in their society and how societies interacr with each other. It seeks to explain interactions forms hypothisis test them and suggest potential actions. Applied social science is about putting theories in to practice and interfacing directly with the public. This doesnt mean an applied social society practioner ie a social worker is isolated from the body of practise far from it they give feed back on the various strategies developed and identify areas where further research could be focused

Just exactly how it sounds. Social science is the study of society and its structure and dynamics. Applied social science takes that knowledge and applies it to real world problems. Some areas are Applied anthropology—working in business, government, public service to analyze cultural dynamics to solve practical problems in areas like marketing, develoment problems Social work—helping individuals negotiate bureaucracy and social services Applied edonomics—using economic theory to solve problems like agricultural finance, urban development, housing, and merchandizing. Every discipline has an applied field. If you visit the websites for any of these disciplines, you will be able to explore these applied fields.

Question - “What is the relationship of social science to applied social science?” Answer - Huh?!??! There is none. More to the point, the words ‘social’ or ‘political’ and ‘science’ must NEVER be used together, as there is absolutely nothing scientific, or in any way related to true science or the scientific method, when it comes to ‘political’ or ‘social’ issues. These are made up terms designed to make the practitioners of these fraudulent field feel better about themselves, and what they engage in. Period.

Beats me. Social science. Well I would assume, that would relate to the science of groups. An examination of groups, how they are formed, developed and how they interact with other groups. Applied science would probably be a bunch of cloistered sociologist trying to manufacture a solution to a perceived shortcoming of various groups. But be wary of academics, there solutions are made in the clouds. Because in reality all groups display great conpassion, and great cruelty. It just depends. Most people are like sheep they follow blindly, the good and the bad.

Social science involves the use of scientific methods and scientific approach to study, to explain and to suggest how to manage all activities taking place in the societies. Applied social science involves how to apply scientifically what we know about our societies to events of the past, present and the future.

Usually, social policies and regulations are often based on results of social science. Where and how are people prone to radicalization in the Netherlands, for example. The results of that study are then implemented in possible governmental policies. How to organize, where to focus on, all that is easier when social science first research the exact problem.

Social science is a major category of academic disciplines, concerned with society and the relationships among individuals within a society. Social science as a whole has many branches, each of which is considered a social science. The social sciences include, but are not limited to: anthropology, archaeology, economics, history, human geography, jurisprudence, linguistics, political science, psychology, public health, and sociology. The term is also sometimes used to refer specifically to the field of sociology, the original "science of society", established in the 19th century. For a more detailed list of sub-disciplines within the social sciences see: Outline of social science.
